$2,100,000 to rehab and upgrade Old Town Hall, the premier public facility in the City of Fairfax and the cultural and social center of the community for 121 years.

My life‚Äôs work is about protecting the health and well-being of my community, and I'm grateful I can do that work every day. (6/6)

I‚Äôm fighting to make health care more affordable for everyone. Because of my Health Care Affordability Act, families are saving an average of $2,400 per year, and a record 14.5 million Americans have signed up for a plan. (5/6)

My Congressman voted for a bill that would prevent people like me from accessing health care.  
 
That moment is what inspired me to run for Congress. (4/6)

A few years later, I happened to go to a town hall that my Congressman hosted in 2017. He said he would only support a version of ACA repeal that would let people with pre-existing conditions keep their health care. I believed him. 
 
Two weeks later, he broke his word. (3/6)

I got my nursing degree and worked for the Department of Health and Human Services to help implement the Affordable Care Act, ensuring that millions of Americans could get covered and access high-quality care ‚Äî some for the first time ever. (2/6)

In honor of the 12th anniversary of the #AffordableCareAct, I wanted to share my story on why I ran for Congress. 
 
I was diagnosed with a heart condition as a child, and the care that I received inspired me to work in health care. (1/6)

If you thought Senator Stevens was legendary and tenacious in his pursuit of federal dollars to help build Alaska‚Äîjust know that Congressman Young was right there with him, every step of the way, making sure Alaska received what we would call our fair share.

He passed legislation to open a small part of the non-wilderness 1002 Area, in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, a dozen times before we steered it into law in 2017.  He never gave up, and his commitment to our energy security should be more appreciated than ever.
Congressman young helped establish the 200-mile fishing limit and contributed to the Magnuson-Stevens Act, which have allowed Alaska to maintain its world-class fisheries.

Congressman Young joined the U.S. House of Representatives in 1973. In his first year in office, he helped authorize the Trans-Alaska Pipeline, which has been Alaska's economic backbone ever since. Not long after, his colleagues chose him as the Freshman Congressman of the Year.

As the only woman on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, I leaned on her for advice and guidance over the years ‚Äì words of wisdom that I‚Äôll always treasure.

Madeleine Albright shattered the glass ceiling at the State Department when she was sworn in as the first female Secretary of State. In the years since, we have seen women follow in her footsteps and stand on her shoulders as public servants, diplomats, and yes ‚Äì U.S. Senators.
We were linked through our common bonds as women working in national security structures, which before her were almost entirely off limits to women.
I‚Äôm honored to have had the opportunity to not only engage with Secretary Albright in my capacity as a lawmaker, but to have enjoyed her company personally.
